Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Impacts of Human Activity on Squid Population in the Coral Reefs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The researcher will study the effects of human populations on the health of coral reefs and also on the reproductive behaviors of the oval squid, a common fisheries species. Squid are an ideal behavioral study organism due to their complex mating displays and behaviors. Populations of squid are directly affected by changes in the environmental factors that support reproduction, including coral bleaching and river runoff. The study will be conducted with Dr. Yuzuru Ikeda at the University of the Ryukyus and will benefit from his expertise in laboratory and field-based cephalopod behavior research. Nearby reefs and sophisticated university facilities will allow completion of two complementary projects. Project 1: field surveys of oval squid population sizes in native reef habitats adjacent to human populations of different size; Project 2: a laboratory study of ideal reproductive habitats for oval squids. Results from these projects can inform future conservation efforts by bolstering understanding of human effects on common fishery species.

The field and laboratory experiments will examine the impact of urbanization on the reproductive behavior and population size of oval squid (Sepioteuthis lessoniana). Project 1: observational studies will be conducted in the reefs near urbanized Okinawa Island and the remote reefs of the Yaeyama Islands to document oval squid egg clusters, sub-adults, adults, and coral species abundances. Project 2: the researcher will perform behavioral studies of squids in artificial reef environments. Groups of 8-10 adult oval squid will experience four habitat conditions ranging between "poor" (empty) and "enriched" (artificial seaweed and corals). Each will be observed daily for mating and spawning behaviors, including courtship signaling, spermatophore transfer, number of eggs, and egg condition. Squid communities are expected to be smaller in urbanized areas, while squid in "poor" tank conditions will show a smaller number of mating behaviors and egg clusters. This project will elucidate the effects of human activity on squid reproduction and inform conservation measures that could be applicable to many reef ecosystems.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Experimental projects completed during the EAPSI program focused on the reproductive behavior of the oval squid, a common shallow-water squid, in Okinawa, Japan. As a guest of Dr. Yuzuru Ikeda, I completed two laboratory experiments testing changes in mating behavior in different habitats with the ultimate goal of learning whether certain a certain habitat is preferable for mating and reproduction. In the first experiment, I provided wild caught squid with three habitats: coral rubble, short seagrass, and long seagrass. In the second experiment, the home tank was further split into six habitats: two of coral rubble, short seagrass, long seagrass, short coral, and long coral.  In both experiments, mating behaviors were observed and location, as well as the ID of actively mating squid, were recorded. I also worked on a collaborative fieldwork project, the ultimate goal of which, is to determine spawning habitat preference, and to compare spawning sites in both urban and rural locations to elucidate potential anthropogenic effects on oval squid reproduction. These experiments may determine the preferred habitat for oval squid mating and spawning as well as further detail of the reproductive behavior of a dynamic cephalopod species.

The experiments completed as part of the EAPSI fellowship may provide detailed findings that could be used in creating management or conservation measures. Both projects will define details of the reproductive process in oval squid that could be key to their successful long-term status as a fisheries species. Knowledge of preferred habitat for mating and spawning could lead to protection of that habitat to ensure healthy populations. Eventually the collaborative fieldwork experiment could determine if there are impacts of urbanization on the spawning of this shallow-water species.

The results of these experiments will be shared with other scientists as well as students in the U.S. In general, squid are a charismatic animal which often fosters not only scientific interest but public interest. The experiments will be presented at scientific conferences, used as a tool for teaching research methods to undergraduates, and presented to high schoolers as part of a STEM seminar. I work closely with diverse students in Brooklyn College and Erasmus Hall High School as a mentor and educator. The experiments completed during the EAPSI program will be invaluable in sparking interest in animal behavior, ecology, evolution, and conservation; knowledge which could lead students to STEM-based higher education and careers.

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2018
Modified by: Naomi J Lewandowski
